perturbation.original_text: (a) Service Provider shall prepare and maintain all reports and other information relating to the SEF maintenance (the "SEF O&M Reports") and  make such SEF O&M Reports available to Owner (i) within ten (10) business days following performance of any Services under this Agreement  and (ii) upon reasonable request at any time
perturbation.changed_text: (a) Service Provider shall prepare and maintain all reports and other information relating to the SEF maintenance (the "SEF O&M Reports") and  make such SEF O&M Reports available to Owner (i) within thirty (30) business days following performance of any Services under this Agreement  and (ii) upon reasonable request at any time
perturbation.explanation: California law mandates that records pertaining to employee exposure to potentially hazardous materials (which could conceivably occur during SEF maintenance) must be accessible within 15 days of a request. Changing the response time to 30 days creates a contradiction with state law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 3204(e)(1)(B) - Access to Employee Exposure and Medical Records

perturbation.original_text: 3.2 Obligations Following Termination. Within five (5) days after the termination or expiration of this Agreement, and upon Owner's payment in full  of the amounts due Service Provider under the Agreement, Service Provider shall deliver to Owner all of the SEF O&M Reports, SEF books,  records and property in its possession or under its control, and all materials, supplies, consumables, manuals and any other items furnished to  Service Provider by Owner.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.2 Obligations Following Termination. Within fifteen (15) days after the termination or expiration of this Agreement, and upon Owner's payment in full  of the amounts due Service Provider under the Agreement, Service Provider shall deliver to Owner all of the SEF O&M Reports, SEF books,  records and property in its possession or under its control, and all materials, supplies, consumables, manuals and any other items furnished to  Service Provider by Owner.
perturbation.explanation: California Labor Code Section 201 dictates that when an employee is discharged, their unpaid wages are due and payable immediately. California Labor Code Section 202 dictates that if an employee quits, his or her wages are due and payable no later than 72 hours. While it is not a wage agreement, this agreement has similarities to a contractor-employee relationship, therefore delaying the delivery of documentation to 15 days would violate this Labor Code Section.

perturbation.original_text: 2.3 Terms of Payment. Owner shall pay Service Provider within thirty (30) days after the invoice date. Fees are conditioned upon timely payment  and any past due balance will accrue interest at the monthly rate of one and one half percent (1.5%).
perturbation.changed_text: 2.3 Terms of Payment. Owner shall pay Service Provider within sixty (60) days after the invoice date. Fees are conditioned upon timely payment  and any past due balance will accrue interest at the monthly rate of one and one half percent (1.5%).
perturbation.explanation: California Prompt Payment Act requires payments to small business contractors by state and local governments to be made within 30 days. By changing the payment term to 60 days, the contract violates this act, potentially delaying payments to the Service Provider and subjecting the Owner to penalties.
perturbation.contradicted_law: California Prompt Payment Act (California Public Contract Code Section 7107)
